Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; part of lotus in added white outline and added red centres; exterior: band of Z between pairs of bands; below, black-figure decoration consisting of edge of siren’s wing to left.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR 97.1894, which in turn joins British Museum 1888,0601.550.b. The sherd belongs to the group of Chian black-figured vases bearing Laconising features. According to Williams, the chalice is by the same painter who decorated the cups Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.2 and AN1896-1908-G.133.6, whom he has identified as the Sirens Painter. The Sirens Painter pieces most closely resemble those by the Laconian Boreads Painter, primarily because of the single pomegranate band on the tondo of the Oxford kylix. Lemos incorrectly identifies this sherd as belonging to a Black Figure Komast Cup.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 328, no. 1528)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 130, p. 132, note 67)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0874) (phase 2)
